How I Went From Intern to Senior Data Analyst in 5 Years

The honest story of my journey from Capital One intern to Senior Analyst at Stripe—including the mistakes, the pivots, and what actually moved the needle.

Career Data Analytics Growth

Five years ago I was a nervous intern at Capital One, trying to figure out how JOIN worked in SQL. Today I’m a Senior Data Analyst at Stripe, leading a team and presenting to VPs. Here’s what actually moved the needle—and what I wasted time on.

What I Got Right

1. I learned to communicate before I learned to model

The single biggest separator between mid-level and senior analysts isn’t technical skill—it’s the ability to translate a complex finding into a clear business recommendation.

Early in my career I gave an 18-slide deck full of confidence intervals to a VP who wanted to know: should we expand to the UK market? He stopped me after slide 3.

I rebuilt the presentation as: problem → recommendation → evidence. Three slides. He approved the project.

The goal of analysis is a decision, not a deliverable.

2. I picked depth over breadth in my second year

The temptation as a new analyst is to learn everything: SQL, Python, R, Tableau, Power BI, Spark, Looker, dbt…

I got much more value from going deep on Python + SQL + one BI tool than from being mediocre at everything. When you’re the team’s Python expert, people come to you. When you’re “okay at everything,” people go to the specialist.

3. I got close to a domain

At Shopify I specialised in merchant health. I became the person who understood churn inside out—not just the models, but why merchants leave, what interventions work, what the product team was trying to do. That context made my analysis 10x more useful than technically superior work done without it.

4. I built in public (sort of)

Writing internal write-ups of my analyses, sharing findings in Slack, volunteering to present at data team all-hands—all of these compounded my visibility over time. People outside my immediate team started tagging me when they had data questions.

What I Wasted Time On

Chasing certifications before building projects

I spent three months of evenings on a cloud certification that nobody has ever asked me about in an interview. The project I built the month after that—a churn model for a nonprofit using Kaggle data—came up in every subsequent conversation.

Build things. Then document them. The certification is the resume line; the project is the interview.

Perfecting analyses nobody read

I once spent two weeks refining a segmentation model. By the time I was done, the product team had already made the decision it was supposed to inform.

Ship an 80% analysis on time, then iterate. A good-enough answer today beats a perfect answer next month.

Optimising for title vs learning

I turned down a senior analyst role at a small company to stay at Shopify as an analyst II, because I knew I’d learn more from the Shopify infrastructure and team. Two years later I got promoted to senior and then lateral-hired at Stripe at a higher level than the role I’d turned down.

Optimise for slope, not intercept.

The Skills That Actually Got Me Hired

Every recruiter screen, every final round, every hiring manager I’ve talked to cared about:

  1. SQL proficiency — this is table stakes at any data role. Window functions, CTEs, query optimisation.
  2. Storytelling with data — can you explain a complex finding simply?
  3. Business intuition — can you connect the data to a business outcome?
  4. Technical curiosity — are you self-teaching, staying current, building things?

Python and ML were nice-to-haves that differentiated me once I was through the door. They weren’t what got me in.

Advice I’d Give My 2019 Self

  • Find a senior analyst whose work you admire and ask to review your work with them monthly. Most people will say yes.
  • Write up your analyses even when nobody asks. The habit of documenting decisions is worth its weight in gold.
  • Develop a point of view. Analysts who only report what the data says are replaceable. Analysts who say “here’s what I think we should do, and here’s why” become indispensable.
  • Your first company matters less than the people you learn from there.

Happy to chat about any of this—reach out on LinkedIn or drop me an email.
